posts.cooked:
We’ve used MAXSwerve with NEOs for two seasons.  We are considering upgrading to NEO Vortex for higher performance. We’d like to be faster. That said, we have other things we could work on and we are very careful with our budget.

For teams that have upgraded, can you comment on the value and experience?  Is there a noticeable performance improvement?

posts.name: Jsteel
posts.cooked: We started using MaxSwerve this last year, and we started with the Vortex motors.  Short answer - they worked great for us. No significant problems during a long competition year.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
We haven’t used them yet, but plan to next year. Not having to fiddle with the little JST connectors or gluing the keys is reason enough.

How much performance different you’ll feel is hard to say. With the fast ratio 4.71:1 the sprint time for 50 feet is only slightly different.

Neo Vortex: 3.061 Seconds ( Drivetrain Simulator - AMB Robotics Calculator (ambcalc.com) ) Neo: 3.21 Seconds ( Drivetrain Simulator - AMB Robotics Calculator (ambcalc.com) )

Take the results with a grain of salt.

Edit: I forgot to change the wheel diameter to 3in but the point still stands

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Overall MAXSwerve with Vortexes worked out great for us. Encountered some early bugs in firmware and the API, but they were fixed relatively quickly.

posts.name: Sam Viesselman
posts.cooked:
We made the upgrade this season. I don’t have any qualitative numbers handy, but we differently noticed some gains from the overall higher power output compared the Neos

Our favorite thing was the packaging of the Vortex and not needing to mess with the key on the Neo. Getting rid of one Spark per module cleaned up our wiring significantly and removed the common encoder cable failure point.

Thanks for the replies. We were thinking we would use the solo adapters to reduce the cost. The wiring would be less elegant, but it reduces the cost significantly. Sounds like everyone so far is using the SparkFlex?

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
We ended up with the solos for our vortexes because the flex controllers were sold out at that point. Having used the solo/vortex for our shooter motor it would’ve been nice to not have the spark Max in the subsystem too. If we were doing our swerve modules with vortexes we would absolutely get the flexes instead.

Less wiring, and less failure points is always worth trying to work towards.

posts.name: David Allred
posts.cooked:
This is also our first year with MaxSwerve.   We built an off season bot last year with NEOs then switched to Vortex/Flex for the competition season with the higher speed gear set.    We have no direct comparison between the two setups but do know we ran faster.   Just can’t recall how much faster.

The higher resolution Vortex encoders did not improve swerve odometry.   Don’t know if that is an issue with the MaxSwerve code template and/or the API interface with the controllers.

David

posts.name: Travis Norris
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

Less wiring, and less failure points is always worth trying to work towards.

Second this! The biggest advantage is wiring with the Spark Flex. The most common issue we’ve had with the MaxSwerve over 2 seasons has been broken encoder wires on the Neo or the 550.

The extra power is nice, but not a game changer compared to the simpler assembly.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Head Coach - FRC 2423 | NEMC Planning Committee

posts.custom_user_title: Head Coach - FRC 2423 | NEMC Planning Committee

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
You’ll want to change some settings to set average encoder depth and measurement period.

For a Spark Flex you’ll want an average depth of 8, and measurement period of 32ms.

posts.name: David Allred
posts.cooked: Thanks!   I’ll pass that on to my software team.
